metadata.title: Severe Acute Respiratory Syndrome-associated Coronavirus Infection

abstract.original_text: Whether severe acute respiratory syndrome-associated coronavirus (SARS-CoV) infection can be asymptomatic is unclear. We examined the seroprevalence of SARS-CoV among 674 healthcare workers from a hospital in which a SARS outbreak had occurred. A total of 353 (52%) experienced mild self-limiting illnesses, and 321 (48%) were asymptomatic throughout the course of these observations. None of these healthcare workers had antibody to SARS CoV, indicating that subclinical or mild infection attributable to SARS-CoV in adults is rare.

sentences.segment_text: Whether severe acute respiratory syndrome-associated coronavirus ( SARS-CoV ) infection can be asymptomatic is unclear .
We examined the seroprevalence of SARS-CoV among 674 healthcare workers from a hospital in which a SARS outbreak had occurred .
A total of 353 ( 52 % ) experienced mild self-limiting illnesses ,
and 321 ( 48 % ) were asymptomatic throughout the course of these observations .
None of these healthcare workers had antibody to SARS CoV ,
indicating that subclinical or mild infection attributable to SARS-CoV in adults is rare .
